page.title: German Parliamentary Committee investigation of the NSA spying scandal

revision.text:
{{Expand German|NSA-Untersuchungsausschuss|date=June 2015}}
The '''German Parliamentary Committee investigation of the NSA spying scandal''' (official title: ''1. Untersuchungsausschuss „NSA“'') was started on March 20, 2014, by the [[German Parliament]] in order to investigate the extent and background of foreign secret services spying in Germany in the light of the [[Global surveillance disclosures (2013–present)]]. The Committee is also in search of strategies on how to protect telecommunication with technical means.<ref>http://dip21.bundestag.de/dip21/btd/18/008/1800843.pdf</ref><ref>[[Deutscher Bundestag]]: [http://www.bundestag.de/bundestag/ausschuesse18/ua/1untersuchungsausschuss 1. Untersuchungsausschuss („NSA“)]</ref>
== Members == The committee is formed by eight members of the German Parliament.<ref>[http://www.bundestag.de/bundestag/ausschuesse18/ua/1untersuchungsausschuss/mitglieder/262992 Mitglieder des NSA-Untersuchungsausschusses], bundestag.de, accessed July 7, 2014</ref> The parliamentarian of the [[Christian Democratic Union (Germany)|Christian Democratic Union (CDU)]] [[Clemens Binninger]] was head of the committee but stepped down after six days. In a statement, Binninger clarified that the other committee members had insisted on inviting Edward Snowden to testify; Binninger objected to this and resigned in protest.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bundestag.de/dokumente/textarchiv/2014/50515028_kw15_binninger/216908|title=Deutscher Bundestag - NSA-Untersuchungsausschuss: Binninger tritt vom Ausschussvorsitz zurück|author=Karl Otto Sattler|date=9 April 2014|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[http://www.zeit.de/politik/deutschland/2014-04/nsa-untersuchungsausschuss-binninger-ruecktritt NSA-Ausschussvorsitzender geht im Streit], Zeit.de, April 14, 2014</ref> [[Patrick Sensburg]] (CDU) succeeded him. {| |- style="vertical-align:top" | {| class="wikitable" style="width:405px;border-style: solid; border-width: 2px;border-color:#b5e61d;" ! colspan= "3" style="background-color:#b5e61d;"| Members of the Committee |- style="background-color:#FFDEAD" ! Position ! Name ! Party |- | Chairman | [[Patrick Sensburg]] | CDU |- | Deputy Chairman | [[Hans-Ulrich Krüger]] | [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|SPD]] |- | Member | [[Christian Flisek]] | SPD |- | Member | [[Roderich Kiesewetter]] | CDU |- | Member | [[Andrea Lindholz]] | [[Christian Social Union in Bavaria|CSU]] |- | Member | [[Konstantin von Notz]] | [[Alliance 90/The Greens|The Greens]] |- | Member | [[Martina Renner]] | [[The Left (Germany)|The Left]] |- | Member | [[Tankred Schipanski]] | CDU |} | style="vertical-align:top" | {| class="wikitable" style="width:260px; border-style: solid; border-width: 2px;border-color:#ffc90e;" ! colspan= "3" style="background-color:#ffc90e;"| Deputy Members |- style="background-color:#FFDEAD" ! Name ! Party |- | [[Marian Wendt]] || CDU |- | [[Susanne Mittag]] || SPD |- | [[Burkhard Lischka]] || SPD |- | [[Stephan Mayer]] || CSU |- | [[Tim Ostermann]] || CDU |- | [[Hans-Christian Ströbele]] || The Greens |- | [[André Hahn (Politiker)|André Hahn]] || The Left |- | [[Nina Warken]] || CDU |} | style="vertical-align:top" | {| class="wikitable" style="width:250px;border-style: dotted; border-width: 2px;border-color:#bcbcbc;" ! colspan= "3" style="background-color:#bcbcbc;"| Former Members |- style="background-color:#FFDEAD" ! Name ! Party |- | [[Clemens Binninger]] || CDU |} |} {{clear}}
== Witnesses ==
=== Discussion about the witness Snowden === On May 8, 2014, the committee unanimously decided to let US whistleblower [[Edward Snowden]] testify as a witness.<ref>[http://www.zeit.de/politik/deutschland/2014-05/sensburg-schlaegt-snowden-befragung-in-schweizer-botschaft-vor NSA-Ausschusschef will Snowden in Schweizer Botschaft befragen], zeit.de, May 11, 2014</ref>
On September 23, 2014, the [[Alliance '90/The Greens|Green Party]] and [[The Left (Germany)|The Left]] filed a constitutional complaint against the Christian Democratic Union, the Social Democrats and the NSA Parliamentary Committee because of the Christian Democrats' and the Social Democrats' refusal to let the witness Edward Snowden testify in Berlin. The accused proposed a video conference from Moscow which Snowden had refused.<ref>[http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/abhoer-affaere-opposition-klagt-wegen-snowden-vernehmung-in-krlsruhe-13175658.html ''Grüne und Linke klagen gegen NSA-Untersuchungsauss'', September 26, 2014]. Website FAZ, accessed September 26, 2014</ref>
On September 28, 2014, the Green Party and The Left filed a constitutional complaint against German chancellor Merkel. According to them, she refuses to comply with her duty according to Chapter 44 of the German constitution to ensure a real investigation; especially by refusing to ensure the legal requirements to allow the witness Edward Snowden to testify.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/nsa-spaehaffaere-opposition-verklagt-merkel-wegen-snowden-a-994029.html|title=NSA Sphaffre: Opposition verklagt Merkel wegen Snowden - SPIEGEL ONLINE|author=((SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg, Germany))|date=28 September 2014|work=SPIEGEL ONLINE}}</ref>
=== Testimony of Binney and Drake === On July 3, 2014, the former Technical Director of the NSA, [[William Binney (U.S. intelligence official)|William Binney]], who had become a whistleblower after the [[9/11|terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001]], testified to the committee. He said that the NSA has a totalitarian approach that has previously only been known from dictatorships and that there is no longer such a thing as privacy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuttgarter-zeitung.de/inhalt.nsa-untersuchungsausschuss-9-11-hat-alles-veraendert.aeedf44b-6825-4583-a740-0c20c0bd723a.html|title=NSA-Untersuchungsausschuss: 9/11 hat alles verändert - Politik - Stuttgarter Zeitung|author=Stuttgarter Zeitung|location=Stuttgart, Germany|date=3 July 2014|work=stuttgarter-zeitung.de}}</ref><ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/william-binney-als-zeuge-im-nsa-untersuchungsausschuss-a-979062.html Untersuchungsausschuss im Bundestag: US-Informant vergleicht NSA mit einer Diktatur], Der Spiegel, July 3, 2014</ref> Former NSA employee [[Thomas Andrews Drake]] described the close cooperation between the NSA and the German foreign intelligence service [[Bundesnachrichtendienst|BND]].<ref>[http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/thomas-drake-im-nsa-untersuchungsausschuss-13027055.html Bundesnachrichtendienst „ein Wurmfortsatz der NSA“], FAZ July 4, 2014</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/ex-nsa-mitarbeiter-drake-bnd-unterstuetzte-drohnenkrieg-der-usa-a-979130.html|title=Ex-NSA-Mitarbeiter Drake: BND untersttzte Drohnenkrieg der USA|author=((SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg, Germany))|date=4 July 2014|work=SPIEGEL ONLINE}}</ref>
=== Failed testimony of Greenwald === The US journalist [[Glenn Greenwald]] was asked to testify in September, 2014. On August 1, 2014, he wrote in a letter that he was willing to support the Parliament's investigation on the espionage in Germany by the NSA. By their refusal to let the crucial witness Edward Snowden testify, German politicians had however shown that it is more important to them not to annoy the US than to really investigate and he was not willing to take part in a "ritual" that "shall seem like an investigation".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/glenn-greenwald-sagt-zeugenvernehmung-vor-nsa-ausschuss-ab-a-984030.html|title=Glenn Greenwald sagt Zeugenvernehmung vor NSA-Ausschuss ab|author=((SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg, Germany))|date=1 August 2014|work=SPIEGEL ONLINE}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://netzpolitik.org/2014/glenn-greenwald-sagt-untersuchungsausschuss-ab-ritual-das-die-illusion-einer-untersuchung-erwecken-soll|title=Glenn Greenwald sagt Untersuchungsausschuss ab: "Ritual, das die Illusion einer Untersuchung erwecken soll"|work=netzpolitik.org}}</ref>
==Operation Eikonal selectors== In [[Operation Eikonal]] German [[Federal Intelligence Service (Germany)|BND]] agents received "Selector Lists" from the NSA − search terms for their dragnet surveillance. They contain IP addresses, mobile phone numbers and email accounts with the BND surveillance system containing hundreds of thousands and possibly more than a million such targets.<ref name=spiegel1>{{cite web|title=Spying Close to Home: German Intelligence Under Fire for NSA Cooperation - SPIEGEL ONLINE - International|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/german-intelligence-agency-bnd-under-fire-for-nsa-cooperation-a-1030593.html|publisher=SPIEGEL ONLINE|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref> These lists have been subject of controversy as in 2008 it was revealed that they contained some terms targeting the [[European Aeronautic Defence and Space Company]] (EADS), the [[Eurocopter]] project<ref name="ts1">{{cite web|url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/politik/bnd-und-nsa-die-chronologie-des-spionageskandals/11722810.html|title=BND und NSA: Die Chronologie des Spionageskandals – Politik – Tagesspiegel|work=tagesspiegel.de|language=German}}</ref> as well as French administration,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/die-neue-bnd-affaere-ein-foul-mit-folgen-1.2448810|title=Wie die NSA europäische Unternehmen ausspionierte|work=Süddeutsche.de|language=German}}</ref><ref name=spiegel1/> which were first noticed by BND employees in 2005.<ref name="ts1" /> Other selectors were found to target the administration of Austria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/inland/nsa-spitzelei-bnd-soll-12-000-suchbegriffe-geloescht-haben-13569002.html|title=NSA-Spitzelei: BND soll 12.000 Suchbegriffe gelöscht haben|publisher=Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung GmbH|date=1 May 2015|language=German}}</ref> After the revelations made by whistleblower Edward Snowden the BND decided to investigate the issue whose October 2013 conclusion was that at least 2,000 of these selectors were aimed at Western European or even German interests which has been a violation of the Memorandum of Agreement that the US and Germany signed in 2002 in the wake of the [[September 11 attacks|9/11 terror attacks]].<ref name=spiegel1/> After reports emerged in 2014 that EADS and Eurocopter had been surveillance targets the [[The Left (Germany)|Left Party]] and the [[Greens (Germany)|Greens]] filed an official request to obtain evidence of the violations.<ref name=spiegel1/><ref>{{cite web|title=Bundesverfassungsgericht - BVerfG, Beschluss des Zweiten Senats vom 13. n|url=https://www.bundesverfassungsgericht.de/SharedDocs/Entscheidungen/DE/2016/10/es20161013_2bve000215.html|website=bundesverfassungsgericht.de|accessdate=4 January 2017|language=de|date=13 October 2016}}</ref>
The investigative Parliamentary Committee was set up in spring 2014 and reviewed the selectors and discovered 40,000 suspicious search parameters, including espionage targets in Western European governments and numerous companies. The group also confirmed suspicions that the NSA had systematically violated German interests and concluded that the Americans could have perpetrated [[economic espionage]] directly under the Germans' noses.<ref name=spiegel1/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Denkler|first1=Thorsten|title=Geheimdienst-Affäre: NSA jubelte BND deutsche Spähziele unter|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/geheimdienst-affaere-nsa-jubelte-bnd-deutsche-spaehziele-unter-1.2715253|publisher=Süddeutsche Zeitung|accessdate=4 January 2017|language=de}}</ref> The investigative parliamentary committee was not granted access to the NSA's selectors list as an appeal led by opposition politicians failed at Germany's top court - instead the ruling coalition appointed an administrative judge, [[Kurt Graulich]], as a "person of trust" who was granted access to the list and briefed the investigative commission on its contents after analyzing the 40,000 parameters.<ref>{{cite web|title=German Constitutional Court rules out access to NSA's 'selectors' list|url=http://www.dw.com/en/german-constitutional-court-rules-out-access-to-nsas-selectors-list/a-36396385|publisher=Deutsche Welle|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Designierter NSA-Sonderermittler: Ein Mann, 40.000 brisante Daten|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/nsa-sonderermittler-kurt-graulich-ein-mann-40-000-datensaetze-a-1040661.html|publisher=SPIEGEL ONLINE|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref> In his almost 300-paged report<ref>{{cite web|title=Der Graulich-Abschlussbericht|url=https://www.tagesschau.de/inland/graulich-abschlussbericht-101.pdf|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref> Graulich concluded that European government agencies were targeted massively and that Americans hence broke contractual agreements. He also found that German targets which received special protection from surveillance of domestic intelligence agencies by [[Basic Law for the Federal Republic of Germany|Germany's Basic Law (Grundgesetz)]] − including numerous enterprises based in Germany − were featured in the NSA's wishlist in a surprising plenitude.<ref>{{cite web|title=Geheimdienstaffäre: Sonderermittler spricht von klarem Vertragsbruch der NSA|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/nsa-selektorenliste-kurt-graulich-spricht-von-klarem-vertragsbruch-a-1060280.html|publisher=SPIEGEL ONLINE|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref> While the magnitude differs there have also been problematic BND-internal selectors which have been used until end of 2013 - around two thirds of 3300 targets were related to EU and NATO states.<ref>{{cite web|title=Geheimdienstkontrolleure: BND hat gegen Recht und Auftrag verstoßen|url=https://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Geheimdienstkontrolleure-BND-hat-gegen-Recht-und-Auftrag-verstossen-3045627.html|publisher=Heise Online|accessdate=4 January 2017|language=de-DE}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=BND hat jahrelang unter Freunden spioniert|url=http://www.dw.com/de/bnd-hat-jahrelang-unter-freunden-spioniert/a-19393446|publisher=Deutsche Welle|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Decker|first1=Markus|title=Geheimdienst-Affäre: BND spitzelte mit eigenen Selektoren|url=http://www.fr-online.de/datenschutz/geheimdienst-affaere-bnd-spitzelte-mit-eigenen-selektoren,1472644,32163156.html|publisher=Frankfurter Rundschau|accessdate=4 January 2017|language=de}}</ref> [[Klaus Landefeld]], member of the board at the Internet industry association Eco International, has met intelligence officials and legislators to present suggestions for improvement, like streamlining the selector system.<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web|last1=Somaskanda|first1=Sumi|title=Is Big Brother coming to Germany?|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2016/12/big-brother-coming-germany-161213062129779.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref> <!--[[de:Selektor (Geheimdienstabfrage)]]-->
== Spying on the committee == On July 4, 2014, it was revealed to the public that BND agent Markus R. had been arrested on July 2, 2014, for apparently having spied. The 31-year-old German is accused of having worked for the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]].<ref name="SZ_2032849">[http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/neue-medienberichte-festgenommener-bnd-mann-spionierte-auch-fuer-die-cia-1.2032849 Medien: Festgenommener BND-Mann spionierte für CIA], Süddeutsche.de, July 6, 2014</ref> After his arrest, the US ambassador [[John B. Emerson]] was summoned for talks at the German [[Foreign Office (Germany)|Foreign Office]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.taz.de/Untersuchungsausschuss-zur-NSA/!141758/|title=BNDler soll für USA spioniert haben: Der amerikanische Brieföffner - taz.de|author=taz. die tageszeitung|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/nsa-ausschuss-bnd-mitarbeiter-unter-spionageverdacht-1.2030878|title=BND-Mitarbeiter soll NSA-Ausschuss ausspioniert haben|work=Süddeutsche.de}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tagesschau.de/inland/festnahme-spion-100.html|title=31-Jähriger festgenommen: BND-Mitarbeiter ein US-Spion? - tagesschau.de|date=5 July 2014|work=tagesschau.de}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/bnd-spion-us-botschafter-emerson-ins-auswaertige-amt-gebeten-a-979318.html|title=BND-Spion: US-Botschafter Emerson ins Auswrtige Amt gebeten|author=((SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg, Germany))|date=4 July 2014|work=SPIEGEL ONLINE}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/bnd-spion-berlin-zoegert-wie-bei-nsa-mit-reaktionen-gegenueber-obama-a-979526.html|title=BND-Spion: Berlin zgert wie bei NSA mit Reaktionen gegenber Obama|author=((SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg, Germany))|date=6 July 2014|work=SPIEGEL ONLINE}}</ref>
It was revealed that the BND-agent had saved 218 secret BND documents on USB sticks since 2012 and sold them to US agents for a sum of 25,000 Euro in Salzburg, Austria. At least three of the documents were about the NSA Parliamentary Committee.<ref name="SZ_2032849" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Festnahme-BND-Mitarbeiter-soll-NSA-Untersuchungsausschuss-ausspioniert-haben-2249652.html|title=Festnahme: BND-Mitarbeiter soll NSA-Untersuchungsausschuss ausspioniert haben|date=4 July 2014|work=heise online}}</ref> The [[Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution]] had mistaken him for a Russian spy and asked US colleagues to help uncover him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/bnd-verfassungsschutz-wollte-agenten-mit-us-hilfe-enttarnen-a-979416.html|title=BND: Verfassungsschutz wollte Agenten mit US-Hilfe enttarnen|author=((SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg, Germany))|date=5 July 2014|work=SPIEGEL ONLINE}}</ref>
On July 9, 2014, a second US spy was discovered, who worked for the Secretary of Defense.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tagesschau.de/inland/nsa-spionageaffaere-razzia-100.html|title=Durchsuchung in Berlin: Weiterer US-Spion enttarnt?|date=9 July 2014|work=tagesschau.de}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/ausweitung-der-geheimdienstaffaere-ermittlungen-gegen-us-spion-im-verteidigungsministerium-1.2038151|title=Zweiter US-Spion im Verteidigungsministerium|work=Süddeutsche.de}}</ref>
In July 2014 a Parliament technician found out that the mobile phone of [[Roderich Kiesewetter]], representative of the Christian Democratic Union in the committee, was spied on. Kiesewetter said there is evidence that all four Party representatives in the committee have been spied on.<ref>http://www.swr.de/landesschau-aktuell/bw/ulm/kiesewetter-offenbar-abgehoert/-/id=1612/did=13735756/nid=1612/1hqz7ou/index.html</ref>
== Document leaks == In the months following May 2015, [[Peter Pilz]], a member of the Austrian parliament for the [[The Greens – The Green Alternative|Green Party]], disclosed several documents and transcripts related to [[operation Eikonal]], in which NSA and BND cooperated for tapping transit cables at a facility of [[Deutsche Telekom]] in Frankfurt. These documents were highly sensitive and handed over to the committee for investigating the Eikonal operation. Therefore, it seems likely someone from the committee leaked these documents to Pilz. Among them are lists of communication channels from many European countries, including most of Germany's neighbours.<ref>Electrospaces.net: [http://electrospaces.blogspot.nl/2015/11/unnoticed-leak-answers-and-raises.html Unnoticed leak answers and raises questions about operation Eikonal], November 22, 2015</ref> Peter Pilz also discovered NSA spying facilities in Austria, and therefore wants a parliamentary committee on the NSA spying in his own country too.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.format.at/articles/1430/930/376970/spionage-peter-pilz-nsa-untersuchungsausschuss|title=Spionage: Peter Pilz fordert einen NSA-Untersuchungsausschuss|author=news networld Internetservice GmbH|work=format.at}}</ref>
On December 1, 2016, [[WikiLeaks]] released over 2,400 documents which it claims are from the investigation.<ref>{{cite web |last=Uchill |first=Joe |url=http://thehill.com/policy/cybersecurity/308407-wikileaks-drops-docs-on-inquiry-into-nsa-german-cooperation |title=WikiLeaks publishes docs on inquiry into German cooperation with NSA |work=The Hill |date=December 1, 2016 |accessdate=December 2, 2016}}</ref>

The '''Global Burden of Disease Study''' ('''GBD''') is a comprehensive regional and global research program of [[disease burden]] that assesses [[death|mortality]] and [[disability]] from major diseases, injuries, and [[risk factor]]s. GBD is a collaboration of over 1,800 researchers from 127 countries. Under principal investigator [[Christopher J.L. Murray]], GBD is based out of the [[Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation]] (IHME) at the [[University of Washington]] and funded by the [[Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=What does a $100 million public health data revolution look like?|url=http://www.tedmed.com/talks/show?id=17751|website=TEDMED}}</ref>
==History==
The Global Burden of Disease Study began in 1990 as a single [[World Bank]]-commissioned<ref name="sign">{{cite web |url=http://www.healthdata.org/announcement/institute-health-metrics-and-evaluation-and-world-health-organization-sign-new |title=Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation and World Health Organization sign new agreement |publisher=[[Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation]] |accessdate=January 29, 2017 |date=May 2015}}</ref> study, now called GBD 1990.<ref name="aboutgbd" /> The original project quantified the health effects of more than 100 diseases and injuries for eight regions of the world, giving estimates of [[Disease#Morbidity|morbidity]] and [[Mortality rate|mortality]] by age, sex, and region. It also introduced the [[disability-adjusted life year]] (DALY) as a new metric to quantify the burden of diseases, injuries, and [[risk factor]]s,<ref name="pruss-ustun2003">{{cite book|first1=Annette|last1=Prüss-Üstün|first2=C.|last2=Mathers|first3=Carlos|last3=Corvalán|first4=A.|last4=Woodward|title=Assessing the environmental burden of disease at national and local levels: Introduction and methods|year=2003|publisher=World Health Organization|location=Geneva|isbn=9241546204|series=WHO Environmental Burden of Disease Series|volume=1|url=http://www.who.int/quantifying_ehimpacts/publications/9241546204/en/index.html}}</ref><ref name="aboutgbd">{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/healthinfo/global_burden_disease/about/en/index.html|title=About the Global Burden of Disease (GBD) project|work=Health statistics and health information systems|publisher=World Health Organization}}</ref><ref name="globalburden">{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/topics/global_burden_of_disease/en/|title=Global burden of disease|publisher=World Health Organization}}</ref> to aid comparisons. GBD 1990 was "institutionalized" at the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) and the research was "conducted mainly by researchers at [[Harvard University|Harvard]] and WHO".<ref name="sign" />
In 2000–2002, the 1990 study was updated by WHO to include a more extensive analysis using a framework known as ''comparative risk factor assessment''.<ref name="aboutgbd" />
The WHO estimates were again updated for 2004 in ''The global burden of disease: 2004 update'' (published in 2008)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/healthinfo/global_burden_disease/GBD_report_2004update_full.pdf |title=''The global burden of disease: 2004 update'' |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] |year=2008}}</ref> and in ''Global health risks'' (published in 2009).<ref name="aboutgbd" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/healthinfo/global_burden_disease/GlobalHealthRisks_report_Front.pdf |title=''Global health risks: mortality and burden of disease attributable to selected major risks'' |year=2009 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]]}}</ref>
Official DALY estimates had not been updated by WHO since 2004<ref name=who>[http://www.who.int/healthinfo/global_burden_disease/en/ Global Burden of Disease (GBD)] at WHO, 2012</ref> until the Global Burden of Diseases, Injuries, and Risk Factors Study 2010 (GBD 2010), also known as the Global Burden of Disease Study 2010,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.healthdata.org/node/1366 |title=Global Burden of Disease: Massive shifts reshape the health landscape worldwide |publisher=Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation |accessdate=January 30, 2017 |quote=That’s one of the main findings from the Global Burden of Disease Study 2010 (GBD 2010), a collaborative project led by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME) at the University of Washington.}}</ref> was published in December 2012.<ref name="ihme_history" /><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Murray CJ, Vos T, Lozano R, Naghavi M, Flaxman AD, Michaud C, etal | title=Disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) for 291 diseases and injuries in 21 regions, 1990-2010: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2010 | journal=Lancet | year= 2013 | volume= 380 | issue= 9859 | pages= 2197–223 | pmid=23245608 | doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(12)61689-4 }}</ref> The work quantified the burdens of 291 major causes of death and disability and 67 risk factors disaggregated by 21 geographic regions and various age–sex groups.<ref name="GBD2010">{{cite journal |vauthors=Murray CJ, Ezzati M, Flaxman AD, Lim S, Lozano R, Michaud C, etal | title=GBD 2010: design, definitions, and metrics | journal=Lancet | year= 2013 | volume= 380 | issue= 9859 | pages= 2063–6 | pmid=23245602 | doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(12)61899-6 }}</ref><ref name="Watts">{{cite journal|vauthors=Watts C, Cairncross S | title=Should the GBD risk factor rankings be used to guide policy? | journal=Lancet | year= 2013 | volume= 380 | issue= 9859 | pages= 2060–1 | pmid=23245600 | doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(12)62121-7}}</ref> GBD 2010 had the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation as its coordinating center, but was a collaboration between several institutions including WHO and the [[Harvard School of Public Health]].<ref name="GBD2010" /> The work was funded by the Gates Foundation.<ref name="sign" /> The GBD 2010 estimates contributed to WHO's own estimates published in 2013,<ref name="aboutgbd" /> although WHO did not acknowledge the GBD 2010 estimates.<ref name="2014_rudan">{{Cite journal |url=https://assets.documentcloud.org/documents/3406781/RudanComment2013GBD.pdf |first1=Igor |last1=Rudan |first2=Kit Yee |last2=Chan |title=Global health metrics needs collaboration and competition |date=December 18, 2014 |accessdate=January 27, 2017 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(14)62006-7 |journal=[[The Lancet]] |volume=385 |pages=92–94}}</ref><ref name="2017_doughton">{{cite web |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/science/historic-gift-gates-foundation-gives-279-million-to-university-of-washington/ |first=Sandi |last=Doughton |title=Historic gift: Gates Foundation gives $279 million to University of Washington |publisher=''[[The Seattle Times]]'' |date=January 25, 2017 |accessdate=January 25, 2017 |quote=Initially, though, IHME antagonized other health experts, who accused the Seattle institute of arrogance and failing to share data and methods. Its first global health report card was not acknowledged by the World Health Organization.}}</ref>
The Global Burden of Disease Study 2013 (GBD 2013) was published in 2014.<ref name="Lancet2014" /> The first installment, "Smoking Prevalence and Cigarette Consumption in 187 Countries, 1980–2012", was published in the ''[[Journal of the American Medical Association]]'' in January, and further installments were published throughout the year.<ref name="ihme_history" /> IHME continued to act as the coordinating center for the work.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.healthdata.org/gbd/about/history |title=GBD History |publisher= Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation |accessdate=January 30, 2017}}</ref>
In October 2016, Global Burden of Disease Study 2015 (GBD 2015) was published.<ref name="ihme_history" /> The work was still coordinated at IHME.

==Aims==
The GBD has three specific aims:
#To systematically incorporate information on non-fatal outcomes into the assessment of the health status (using a time-based measure of healthy years of life lost due either to premature mortality or to years lived with a disability, weighted by the severity of that disability) #To ensure that all estimates and projections were derived on the basis of objective epidemiological and demographic methods, which were not influenced by advocates. #To measure the burden of disease using a metric that could also be used to assess the cost-effectiveness of interventions. The metric chosen was the DALY.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}}
The burden of disease can be viewed as the gap between current health status and an ideal situation in which everyone lives into old age free of disease and disability. Causes of the gap are premature mortality, disability and exposure to certain risk factors that contribute to illness.
==Results==
The 2013 report showed that global [[life expectancy]] for both sexes increased from 65.3 years in 1990, to 71.5 years in 2013,<ref name="Lancet2014">{{cite journal|author=GBD 2013 Mortality and Causes of Death Collaborators| date=2014|title=Global, regional, and national age–sex specific all-cause and cause-specific mortality for 240 causes of death, 1990–2013: a systematic analysis for the Global Burden of Disease Study 2013|journal=The Lancet|volume=385|issue=9963|pages=117–171|issn=0140-6736|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(14)61682-2|pmid=25530442|pmc=4340604}}</ref> while the number of deaths increased from 47.5 million to 54.9 million over the same interval.<ref name="Lancet2014" /> Progress varied widely across [[demographic]] and national groups. Reductions in age-standardised death rates for [[cardiovascular diseases]] and [[cancers]] in high-income regions, and reductions in child deaths from [[diarrhoea]], [[lower respiratory infections]] and neonatal causes in low-income regions drove the changes. [[HIV/AIDS]] reduced life expectancy in southern [[sub-Saharan Africa]].
For most communicable causes of death both numbers of deaths and age-standardised death rates fell, while for most non-communicable causes, demographic shifts increased numbers of deaths but decreased age-standardised death rates.
Global deaths from injury increased by 10.7%, from 4.3 million deaths in 1990 to 4.8 million in 2013; but age-standardised rates declined over the same period by 21%.<ref name="Lancet2014" /> For some causes of more than 100,000 deaths per year in 2013, age-standardised death rates increased between 1990 and 2013, including HIV/AIDS, [[pancreatic cancer]], [[atrial fibrillation]] and flutter, drug use disorders, [[diabetes]], [[chronic kidney disease]] and [[Sickle-cell disease|sickle-cell anaemias]]. Diarrhoeal diseases, lower respiratory infections, neonatal causes and malaria remain in the top five causes of death in children younger than 5 years. The most important [[pathogens]] are [[rotavirus]] for diarrhoea and [[pneumococcus]] for lower respiratory infections.<ref name="Lancet2014" />
GBD 2015 found that for the first time, annual deaths from [[measles]] had fallen below 100,000 in 2013 and 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.plos.org/speakingofmedicine/2016/11/16/vaccinations-vaccine-science-and-a-new-us-president/ |title=Vaccinations, Vaccine Science, and a New US President {{!}} Speaking of Medicine |publisher=[[PLOS]] |date=November 17, 2016 |accessdate=January 31, 2017 |author=Peter Hotez |quote=Those results include new findings just released by the Gates Foundation-supported Global Burden of Disease 2015 Mortality and Causes of Death Collaborators that found a 75 percent reduction in global measles mortality over the last decade such that (for the first time ever) fewer than 100,000 children died from measles in 2013 and 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thelancet.com/action/showFullTableImage?tableId=tbl3&pii=S0140673614616822 |title=Table 3: Selected causes of global child deaths in 1990 and 2013 |accessdate=January 31, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thelancet.com/action/showFullTableImage?tableId=tbl5&pii=S0140673616310121 |title=Table 5: Global deaths in 2005 and 2015 for all ages and both sexes combined and age-standardised death rates, with percentage change between 2005 and 2015 for 249 causes |accessdate=January 31, 2017}}</ref> It also found that the global annual rate of new HIV infections has largely stayed the same during the past 10 years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nature.com/news/global-rate-of-new-hiv-infections-hasn-t-fallen-in-a-decade-1.20305 |publisher=Nature News & Comment |title=Global rate of new HIV infections hasn't fallen in a decade |accessdate=February 2, 2017 |author=Nisha Gaind |date=July 25, 2016}}</ref>
GBD 2015 also introduced the Socio-demographic Index (SDI) as a measure of a location's socio-demographic development that takes into account average income per person, educational attainment, and [[total fertility rate]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ghdx.healthdata.org/record/global-burden-disease-study-2015-gbd-2015-socio-demographic-index-sdi-1980%E2%80%932015 |title=Global Burden of Disease Study 2015 (GBD 2015) Socio-Demographic Index (SDI) 1980–2015 |website=GHDx |accessdate=February 7, 2017 |publisher=[[Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2016/09/there-s-a-new-ranking-of-the-healthiest-countries-how-is-yours-doing/ |title=There's a new ranking of the healthiest countries. How is yours doing? |publisher=[[World Economic Forum]] |accessdate=February 7, 2017 |date=September 23, 2016 |first=Joe |last=Myers}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(16)31790-1| issn = 0140-6736 | volume = 388| issue = 10053| pages = 1447| last = Lancet| first = The| title = GBD 2015: from big data to meaningful change| journal = The Lancet| accessdate = 2017-02-07| date = 2016-10-08| url = http://thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(16)31790-1/abstract}}</ref>
==Reception==
{{more|Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation#Reception}}
The results of the Global Burden of Disease Study have been cited by ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/18/world/asia/china-coal-health-smog-pollution.html |date=August 17, 2016 |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |title=Coal Burning Causes the Most Air Pollution Deaths in China, Study Finds |author=Edward Wong |accessdate=January 31, 2017}}</ref> ''[[The Washington Post]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/roads-kill-the-toll-of-traffic-accidents-are-rising-in-poor-countries/2014/01/12/b1065922-56d2-11e3-8304-caf30787c0a9_story.html |publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]'' |title=Roads Kill: The toll of traffic accidents is rising in poor countries |accessdate=January 31, 2017 |date=January 13, 2014 |first=}}</ref> [[Vox (website)|Vox]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.vox.com/2015/1/2/7474995/map-years-lost-life |date=March 13, 2015 |author=Dylan Matthews |publisher=Vox |title=The #1 reason people die early, in each country |accessdate=January 31, 2017}}</ref> and ''[[The Atlantic]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2013/01/how-the-world-gets-sick-and-dies/267454/ |publisher=[[The Atlantic]] |title=How the World Gets Sick and Dies |author=Neal Emery |accessdate=January 31, 2017 |date=January 24, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2016/10/how-back-pain-took-over-the-world/503243/ |publisher=''[[The Atlantic]]'' |title=How Back Pain Took Over the World |author=Olga Khazan |accessdate=January 31, 2017 |date=October 7, 2016}}</ref>
The World Health Organization did not acknowledge the GBD 2010 estimates.<ref name="2014_rudan" /><ref name="2017_doughton" />

'''Global Map''' is a set of digital maps that accurately cover the whole globe to express the status of global environment. It is developed through the cooperation of [[National mapping agency|National Geospatial Information Authorities]] (NGIAs) in the world. An initiative to develop Global Map under [[Multilateralism|international cooperation]], the Global Mapping Project, was advocated in 1992 by Ministry of Construction, Japan (MOC) at the time (the current [[Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism (Japan)|Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, Japan]]-MLIT).
Global Map is digital [[geospatial information]] in 1 km [[Optical resolution|resolution]] which satisfies the following conditions: # Covering the whole land area of the [[globe]] # In consistent specifications # Easily accessible by anyone in marginal cost The global geospatial information developed as Global Map mainly consists of the following thematic layers: * [[Transportation]] * [[Border|Boundary]] * [[Drainage]] * Population Centers * [[Elevation]] * [[Vegetation]] （Percent Tree Cover） * [[Land Cover]] * [[Land Use]]
== History of the Global Mapping Project == Since the [[United Nations Conference on the Human Environment]] in 1972, global environmental challenges have been recognized as an issue which is common to humankind. “The United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (the [[Earth Summit]])” in Brazil in 1992 adopted “An action plan of humankind for sustainable development: [[Agenda 21]].” Agenda 21 describes in many parts the importance of information for decision-making to appropriately cope with global environmental challenges. Especially geospatial information is regarded to be critical.
In response to the objectives of Agenda 21 and in recognition of the need for further contribution to the development of geospatial information, the MOC at the time (the current MLIT) advocated, in the same year, the Global Mapping Project, an international cooperation initiative to develop global geospatial information to understand the present status and changes of global environment. This concept was presented at the Fifth United Nations Regional Cartographic Conference for the Americas in New York in 1993. At the same time, resolution<ref>{{cite web |url=http://unstats.un.org/unsd/METHODS/CARTOG/Americas/5/EConf.86.3.pdf |title=Report of the Fifth United Nations Regional Cartographic Conference for the Americas |format=PDF |date=January 1993 |publisher=United Nations Economic and Social Council |accessdate=2012-03-23 }}</ref> calling for the promotion of the development of global geospatial data was adopted at this conference. Following this conference, a similar resolution<ref>{{cite web |url=http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/cartog/Asia_and_Pacific/13/ECONF87.3.pdf |title=Report of the Thirteenth United Nations Regional Cartographic Conference for Asia and the Pacific |format=PDF |date=May 1994 |publisher=United Nations Economic and Social Council |accessdate=2012-03-23 }}</ref> was adopted at Thirteenth United Nations Regional Cartographic Conference for Asia and the Pacific in Beijing in 1994.
In 1996, International Steering Committee for Global Mapping (ISCGM), which consists of heads or its equivalents of NGIAs, was established to promote the Global Mapping Project. Thus the mechanism for the international promotion was formed. The [[Geospatial Information Authority of Japan]] (GSI) has been serving as the secretariat of the ISCGM. In the following year, in 1997, which was five years after the Earth Summit, the nineteenth [[United Nations General Assembly#Special sessions|special session of the United Nations General Assembly]] (19th UNGASS) was held. At the paragraph 112 of the resolution<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.un.org/documents/ga/res/spec/aress19-2.htm |title=Programme for the Further Implementation of Agenda 21 |date=1997-06-28 |publisher=United Nations |accessdate=2012-02-26 }}</ref> adopted by the 19th UNGASS, importance of a supportive environment to enhance national capacities and capabilities for information collection and processing, especially in developing countries, to facilitate public access to information on global environmental issues was mentioned along with the description mentioning the significance of international cooperation, including global mapping, as a means to develop the supportive environment.
As a result of such movement, In 1998, a recommendatory letter to participate in the Global Mapping Project was sent from the [[United Nations]] to NGIAs of respective countries in the world.
Further, at the [[World Summit on Sustainable Development]] (Johannesburg Summit) held in 2002, global mapping was included in the Plan of Implementation.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.un.org/esa/sustdev/documents/WSSD_POI_PD/English/POIToc.htm |title=Johannesburg Plan of Implementation |publisher=Division for Sustainable Development, UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs |accessdate=2011-10-18 }}</ref>

revision.text:
In most discussions, the '''global citizens movement''' is a socio-political process rather than a political organization or party structure. The term is often used synonymously with the [[anti-globalization movement]] or the [[global justice movement]].<ref>Susan George, "Global Citizens Movement: A New Actor for a New Politics," Conference on Reshaping Globalisation: Multilateral Dialogues and New Policy Initiatives, Central European University, Budapest, October 18, 2001, http://www.tni.org/article/global-citizens-movement-new-actor-new-politics.</ref>
"Global citizens movement" has been used by activists to refer to a number of organized and overlapping citizens groups who seek to influence public policy often with the hope of establishing global solidarity on an issue. Such efforts include advocacy on ecological [[sustainability]], corporate responsibility, social justice, and similar progressive issues.
In theoretical discussions of [[social movements]], global citizens movement refers to a complex and unprecedented phenomena made possible by the unique subjective and objective conditions of the [[planetary phase of civilization]].<ref>Orion Kriegman, ''Dawn of the Cosmopolitan: The Hope of a Global Citizens Movement'' (Boston: Tellus Institute, 2006), http://www.tellus.org/pub/Dawn_of_the_Cosmopolitan.pdf.</ref> The term is used to distinguish the latent potential for a profound shift in values among an aware and engaged citizenry from existing transnational citizens movements which tend to focus on specific issues (such as the [[anti-war movement]] or the [[labor movement]]).<ref>J. Guidry, M. Kennedy, and M. Zald, eds., ''Globalizations and Social Movements: Culture, Power, and the Transnational Public Sphere'' (Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press, 2003; Daniel Jakopovich, "The Construction of a Trans-European Labour Movement," ''Capital & Class'' 35, no. 1 (February 2011): 63-79, http://cnc.sagepub.com/content/35/1/63.short.</ref>
==Background== The concept of [[global citizenship]] first emerged among the [[Cynicism (philosophy)|Greek Cynics]] in the 4th Century BCE, who coined the term “[[cosmopolitanism|cosmopolitan]]” – meaning ''citizen of the world''. The [[Stoics]] later elaborated on the concept. The contemporary concept of [[cosmopolitanism]], which proposes that all individuals belong to a single moral community, has gained a new salience as scholars examine the ethical requirements of the [[planetary phase of civilization]].<ref>Kwame Anthony Appiah, ''Cosmopolitanism: Ethics in a World of Strangers'' (New York: W.W. Norton, 2006).</ref>
The idea that today’s objective and subjective conditions have increased the latency for an emergent global civic identity has been argued by the authors of the [[Global Scenario Group]]’s final report ''Great Transition: the Promise and Lure of the Times Ahead''.<ref>Paul Raskin, Tariq Banuri, Gilberto Gallopín, Pablo Gutman, Al Hammond, Robert Kates, and Rob Swart, ''Great Transition: The Promise and Lure of the Times Ahead'' (Boston: Stockholm Environment Institute, 2002), http://www.greattransition.org/gt-essay. See also the sequel to ''Great Transition'': Paul Raskin, ''Journey to Earthland: A Great Transition to Planetary Civilization'' (Boston: Tellus Institute, 2016), http://www.greattransition.org/publication/journey-to-earthland.</ref> Similar arguments for the existence of a latent pool of tens of millions of people ready to identify around new values of earth consciousness have been put forth by such authors as [[Paul Raskin]],<ref>Paul Raskin, ''World Lines: Pathways, Pivots, and the Global Futures'' (Boston: Tellus Institute, 2006), http://www.tellus.org/pub/World%20lines-A%20framework%20for%20exploring%20global%20pathways.pdf.</ref> [[Paul H. Ray]],<ref>Paul Ray and Sherry Anderson, ''The Cultural Creatives: How 50 Million People are Changing the World'' (New York: Three Rivers Press, 2000).</ref> and [[David Korten]].<ref>David Korten, ''The Great Turning: From Empire to Earth Community'' (San Francisco: Berrett-Koehler Publishers, 2007)</ref> Organizations, such as [[Oxfam International]] believe that a global citizens movement rooted in social and economic justice is emerging and is necessary for ending global poverty.<ref>Oxfam International, ''Towards Global Equity: Oxfam International's Strategic Plan, 2001 – 2006'' (Oxford, UK: Oxfam International, 2001).</ref>
==Goals== In the last chapter of his book ''Red Sky at Morning'', [[James Gustave Speth|Gus Speth]] describes the potential for a new type of social movement composed of "we the people, as citizens" rooted in the principles of the [[Earth Charter]] to lead the transition in consciousness and values necessary for the emergence of a new planetary civilization.<ref>James Gustave Speth, ''Red Sky at Morning: America and the Crisis of the Global Environment. A Citizen's Agenda for Action'' (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2004).</ref>
Orion Kriegman, author of [http://www.tellus.org/pub/Dawn_of_the_Cosmopolitan.pdf ''Dawn of the Cosmopolitan: The Hope of a Global Citizens Movement''], states, “Transnational corporations, governments, and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) remain powerful global actors, but all of these would be deeply influenced by a coherent, worldwide association of millions of people who call for priority to be placed on new values of quality of life, human solidarity, and environmental sustainability.”<ref>Kriegman, ''Dawn of the Cosmpolitan.''</ref>
Kriegman distinguishes this "coherent, worldwide association of millions" from the existing fragmented social movements active in the [[World Social Forum]]. These movements tend to be issue-specific – focused on labor, environment, human rights, feminist issues, indigenous struggles, poverty, AIDS, and numerous other interrelated but "siloed" efforts. Coherence among these movements would require a reframing of their work under the rubric of the struggle for a socially just and ecologically sustainable global society and the establishment of an institutional structure to defend the rights of humanity, future generations, and the biosphere.
==Critiques== The major critique of the notion of a global citizens movement centers on the potential for the emergence of solidarity on issues at the global level. Nationalism, racism, and the dominance of the [[Westphalian sovereignty|Westphalian state system]] are considered antithetical to the adoption of a global civic identity. However, some scholars point out that the historical emergence of nationalism must have felt just as improbable in a time of warring city-states,<ref>Benedict Anderson, ''Imagined Communities: Reflections on the Origin and Spread of Nationalism'' (New York: Verso, 1991).</ref> and yet in retrospect it appears inevitable.<ref>Chella Rajan, ''Global Politics and Institutions'' (Boston: Tellus Institute, 2006), http://www.tellus.org/tellus/publication/global-politics-and-institutions-a-utopistic-view.</ref>
A more radical critique stems from the arguments put forth by [[Michael Hardt]] and [[Antonio Negri]] in their book ''[[Multitude]]'' and enshrines [[Michel Foucault]]'s notion of a “plurality of resistance”<ref>Michel Foucault, ''The History of Sexuality'' (New York: Vintage Books, 1980).</ref> as the only legitimate path forward. This argument asserts that an organized movement among the vast multitude is both undesirable and impossible. Instead of leadership and organizational structures, Hardt and Negri put faith in the emergence of spontaneous coherence due to increasing self-organized networks among various autonomous resistance movements. They critique the notion that there could be legitimate leaders, democratically chosen through a formal network of grassroots structures, acting on behalf of a big-tent pluralistic association of global citizens to directly confront the entrenched power of transnational corporations and state governments. However, it remains unclear how a network of autonomous movements would differ in practice from the vision of an authentic global citizens movement.

Boulder: Bauu Press, 2006. {{ISBN|0-9721349-5-6}} * Mayo, Marjorie. ''Global Citizens: Social Movements and the Challenge of Globalization''. '''Health systems strengthening''' (also '''health system strengthening''', abbreviated '''HSS''') is a term used in [[global health]] that roughly means to improve the health care system of a country.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/healthsystems/hss_glossary/en/index5.html |accessdate=June 14, 2016 |title=Health Systems Strengthening Glossary |publisher=[[World Health Organization]]}}</ref> Within this general definition, it can mean increasing funding for health infrastructure, improving health policy, trying to achieve [[universal healthcare]],<ref name="glassman">{{cite web |url=http://files.givewell.org/files/conversations/Amanda%20Glassman%208-27-13.pdf |title=Conversation with Amanda Glassman on August 27, 2013 |accessdate=June 14, 2016 |last=Glassman |first=Amanda |publisher=[[GiveWell]]}}</ref> or any number of other health measures.
There has been some effort to use a [[systems thinking]] approach to health systems strengthening.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.hfgproject.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/New-Perspectives-in-Health-Systems-Strengthening-Executive-Summary.pdf |publisher=USAID |title=New Perspectives in Health Systems Strengthening}}</ref><ref name="systems-thinking-book">{{cite web |url=http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/44204/1/9789241563895_eng.pdf |title=Systems Thinking for Health Systems Strengthening |publisher=World Health Organization |year=2009}}</ref>
==Organizations that use health systems strengthening==
Various health organizations have claimed to use health systems strengthening (while not necessarily agreeing on the definition). Some of these are:
* [[World Health Organization]] * [[US Agency for International Development]] (USAID, uses different definition from the one in a 2006 Global Fund-commissioned WHO report);<ref name=marchal/> USAID states that HSS has been "at the core of [its] mission in health for the last 20 years", and defines HSS as "initiating activities in the six internationally accepted core HSS functions – human resources for health; health finance; health governance; health information; medical products, vaccines, and technologies; and service delivery".<ref name=usaid>{{cite web |url=https://www.usaid.gov/sites/default/files/documents/1864/HSS-Vision.pdf |title=USAID's Vision for Health Systems Strengthening |publisher=USAID |accessdate=June 14, 2016}}</ref> * [[GAVI Alliance]]<ref name=marchal/> * The [[Global Fund]]<ref name=marchal/> * [[PEPFAR]] (though less developed)<ref name=marchal/> * [[Stop TB Partnership]] (uses different definition from the one in a 2006 Global Fund-commissioned WHO report)<ref name=marchal/> * [[Roll Back Malaria]] (uses different definition from the one in a 2006 Global Fund-commissioned WHO report)<ref name=marchal/>
==Reception==
Both the idea of health systems strengthening and the term itself have received attention.
Even advocates of health systems strengthening admit that it can often seem like a "distant, even abstract aim".<ref name=systems-thinking-book/>
Marchal et al., writing in 2009, called the term "vague" and argued that "most current HSS strategies are selective (i.e., they target a specific disease), and their effects may undermine progress towards the long-term goal of effective, high-quality, and inclusive health systems."<ref name="marchal">{{cite web |url=http://journals.plos.org/plosmedicine/article?id=10.1371/journal.pmed.1000059#s2 |title=Global Health Actors Claim To Support Health System Strengthening—Is This Reality or Rhetoric? |authors=Marchal B, Cavalli A, Kegels G |date=April 28, 2009 |publisher=''[[PLOS Medicine]]''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://karengrepin.com/2009/04/are-health-system-strengthening-efforts.html |title=Are health system strengthening efforts just hype? |date=April 29, 2009 |author=Karen Grepin |accessdate=June 14, 2016}}</ref>
[[Peter Berman]], who was the lead health economist at the [[World Bank]], has pointed out that "Almost any support to health interventions can be considered HSS".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTHSD/Resources/376278-1114111154043/1011834-1246449110524/062509BermanUnpackingHealthSystemStrengthening.pdf |author=Peter Berman |date=June 2009 |publisher=World Bank |title=Unpacking Health System Strengthening |accessdate=June 14, 2016}}</ref>
==See also==
* [[Timeline of global health]] * [[Health system#Health systems performance|Health system § Health systems performance]]
