It is both the longest sea crossing{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-45937924|title=China opens longest sea-crossing bridge|date=2018-10-23|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/smooth-start-for-worlds-longest-sea-crossing|title=Smooth start for world's longest state of the art sea crossing|last=hermes|date=2018-10-25|work=The Straits Times|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en}} and the longest [[Intercontinental and transoceanic fixed links|fixed link]] on earth. The HZMB spans the [[Lingdingyang|Lingding]] and [[Jiuzhouyang|Jiuzhou]] channels, connecting [[Hong Kong]], [[Macau]], and [[Zhuhai]]—three major cities on the [[Pearl River Delta]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.caixinglobal.com/2017-12-08/whats-the-cost-of-a-ride-on-the-worlds-longest-bridge-over-water-101182465.html|title=What's the Cost of a Ride on the World's Longest Bridge Over Water? - Caixin Global|website=www.caixinglobal.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-24}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.rt.com/news/434881-longest-bridge-photos-world/|title=Satellite shots show epic scale of world's longest oversea bridge (IMAGES)|work=RT International|access-date=2018-10-24|language=en-US}} The HZMB was designed to last for 120 years and built with a cost of 126.9 billion [[Yuan (currency)|yuan]] (US$ {{To USD|126.9|China}} billion).{{Cite web|url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-10/23/c_137553194.htm|title=Xinhua Headlines: World's longest cross-sea bridge opens, integrating China's Greater Bay Area - Xinhua {{!}} English.news.cn|website=www.xinhuanet.com|access-date=2018-10-27}} The cost of constructing the main bridge was estimated at 51.1 billion yuan (US$ 7.56 billion) funded by bank loans and shared among the governments of mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau.{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/05/04/asia/hong-kong-zhuhai-macau-bridge/index.html|title=China unveils world's longest sea-crossing bridge|last=CNN|first=Sarah Lazarus,|work=CNN|access-date=2018-10-28}} Originally set to be opened to traffic in late 2016,{{Cite web|url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics-Economy/Economy/Hong-Kong-Zhuhai-Macau-Bridge-construction-set-to-finish-this-year|title=Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau bridge construction set to finish this year|website=Nikkei Asian Review|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-10-28}}{{cite web |last1=The Standard |title=Bridge to open in one go despite HK delays |url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/section-news.php?id=173208 |accessdate=22 October 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161022223108/http://www.thestandard.com.hk/section-news.php?id=173208 |archivedate=22 October 2016 |df=dmy-all}} the structure was completed on 6 February 2018{{Cite web|url=http://www.gov.cn/xinwen/2018-02/06/content_5264425.htm |script-title=zh:港珠澳大桥主体工程完成交工验收具备通车试运营条件_滚动新闻_中国政府网|last=刘淼|website=www.gov.cn|access-date=2018-10-27}} and journalists were subsequently given rides over the bridge.{{Cite news |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/05/04/asia/hong-kong-zhuhai-macau-bridge/index.html |title=China unveils world's longest sea-crossing bridge |last=CNN |first=Sarah Lazarus, |work=CNN |access-date=2018-08-16}}{{Cite web |url=http://gd.qq.com/a/20180121/010630.htm |script-title=zh:好消息！港珠澳大桥七一前正式通车_大粤网_腾讯网 |website=gd.qq.com |language=zh-CN |access-date=2018-02-08 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180209002714/http://gd.qq.com/a/20180121/010630.htm |archivedate=9 February 2018 |df=dmy-all}} On 24 October 2018, the HZMB was opened to the public after its inauguration a day earlier by [[Xi Jinping]], [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of China]] and [[President of the People's Republic of China]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-10/23/c_137552885_3.htm|title=Xi announces opening of Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge|website=Xinhua|language=en|access-date=2018-10-23}} == Planning == === Background === [[Hopewell Holdings]] founder and then-managing director [[Gordon Wu]] proposed the concept of a bridge-tunnel linking China, Hong Kong and Macau in the 1980s.{{Cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/hong-kong-economy/article/2169864/property-tycoon-gordon-wus-35-year-dream-massive|title=Tycoon’s 35-year dream finally realised as mega bridge opens|last=Tsang|first=Denise|date=2018-10-23|work=South China Morning Post|access-date=2018-10-23}} Wu stated that he got the idea in 1983 from the [[Chesapeake Bay Bridge–Tunnel]]. In 1988, Wu pitched the concept to Guangdong and Beijing officials. He envisaged a link farther north than the current design, beginning at Black Point near [[Tuen Mun]], Hong Kong and crossing the Pearl River estuary via [[Nei Lingding Island|Neilingding Island]] and [[Qi'ao Island]]. His proposed bridge would end at the Chinese village of Tangjia, and a new road would continue south through Zhuhai before terminating at Macau.{{cite news |last1=Stoner |first1=Tad |title=$6b bridge to China plan |work=South China Morning Post |date=3 November 1988 |page=1}} Discussions stalled after the [[Tiananmen Square protests of 1989|Tiananmen Square massacre]] in mid-1989 "unnerved" Wu and other foreign investors, and caused Hopewell's Hong Kong share prices to plunge.{{cite news |last1=Hunt |first1=Christopher |title=Entrepreneur Becomes a Weather Vane For Resuming Business in China Now |work=The Wall Street Journal, Eastern edition |date=29 December 1989 |page=1}} The route proposed by Wu was promoted by the government of [[Zhuhai]] under the name [[Lingdingyang Bridge]]. In the mid-1990s, Zhuhai built a bridge between the mainland and Qi'ao Island that was intended as the first phase of this route, though the full scheme had not been approved by either the Chinese nor Hong Kong governments at that time.{{cite news |last1=Cheung |first1=Agnes |title=First Lingdingyang link nearly ready |work=South China Morning Post |date=29 March 1995 |page=11}} China's central government showed support for this project on 30 December 1997.{{cite news |last1=Szeto |first1=Wanda |last2=Ng |first2=Kang-chung |title=Beijing approves Zhuhai-HK bridge |work=South China Morning Post |page=1 |date=31 December 1997}} The new Hong Kong government was reticent, stating that it was still awaiting cross-border traffic study results, and Hong Kong media questioned the environmental impact of the project with regard to air pollution, traffic and marine life.{{cite news |title=A bridge too far |work=South China Morning Post |date=2 January 1998 |page=12}} In December 2001, the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong]] passed a motion urging the Administration to develop the logistics industry including the construction of a bridge connecting Hong Kong, Zhuhai and Macao. At a meeting of the China/Hong Kong Conference on Co-ordination of Major Infrastructure Projects held on 20 September 2002, it was agreed that a joint study should be conducted on the transport link between Hong Kong and Pearl River West.{{Cite web|url=https://www.legco.gov.hk/database/english/data_tp/tp-zhuhzi-macao-bridge.htm|title=Hong Kong - Zhuhai - Macao Bridge (HZMB)|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} === Preparation === To coordinate the project, the Advance Work Coordination Group of HZMB was set up in 2003. Officials from three sides solved the issues such as landing points and alignments of the bridge, operations of the Border Crossing Facilities and project financing.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hzmb.org/en/bencandy.asp?id=2|title=Introduction to Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge - Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridg|website=www.hzmb.org|access-date=2018-10-27}} In August 2008, China's Central Government, the governments of [[Guangdong]], Hong Kong and Macau agreed to finance 42% of the total costs. The remaining 58% consisted of loans (approximately 22 billion [[Chinese yuan|yuan]] or US$ 3.23 billion) from [[Bank of China]].{{cite news |first=Mingxin |last=Bi |title=Bank of China to lead loan consortium for Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-04/14/content_11186292.htm |work=Window of China |publisher=Xinhuanet |date=14 April 2009 |accessdate=17 April 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024042455/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-04/14/content_11186292.htm |archivedate=24 October 2012 |df=dmy-all}} In March 2009, it was further reported that China's Central Government, Hong Kong and Macau agreed to finance 22% of the total costs. The remaining 78% consisted of loans (approximately 57.3 billion yuan or US$ 8.4 billion) from a consortium of banks led by [[Bank of China]].{{cite news |first=Jonathan |last=Cheng |title=China Builds Bridge to Link Southern Cities |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB126088119555891949?mod=googlenews_wsj |work=Wall Street Journal |publisher=Dow Jones & Company |date=15 December 2009 |accessdate=15 December 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171013144446/https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB126088119555891949?mod=googlenews_wsj |archivedate=13 October 2017 |df=dmy-all}} == Construction == Construction of the HZMB project began on 15 December 2009 on the Chinese side,[[Arup Group Limited|Arup]]: [http://www.arup.com/News/2010-02_February/09_Feb_2010_Ground-breaking_HK-Zhuhai-Macao_Bridge.aspx "Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge ground breaking"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130719083538/http://www.arup.com/News/2010-02_February/09_Feb_2010_Ground-breaking_HK-Zhuhai-Macao_Bridge.aspx |date=19 July 2013 }}, 9 February 2010. Retrieved 22 December 2011. with then-[[Vice Premier of China]] [[Li Keqiang]] holding a commencement ceremony. Construction of the Hong Kong section of the project began in December 2011 after a delay caused by a legal challenge regarding the environmental impact of the bridge.[[Macau Daily Times]]: [http://www.macaudailytimes.com.mo/macau/32406-Pearl-River-Delta-Bridge-work-begins.html "Pearl River Delta Bridge work begins"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120610180541/http://www.macaudailytimes.com.mo/macau/32406-Pearl-River-Delta-Bridge-work-begins.html |date=10 June 2012 }}, 15 December 2011. Retrieved 22 December 2011. The last bridge tower was erected on 2 June 2016,{{cite web |url=http://en.people.cn/n3/2016/0603/c90000-9067785.html |title=HK-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge about to open to traffic |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160608012540/http://en.people.cn/n3/2016/0603/c90000-9067785.html |archivedate=8 June 2016 |df=dmy-all}}{{cite web |url=http://www.hzmb.org/en/bencandy.asp?id=3075 |title=Final HZMB Bridge Tower Erected |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018224511/http://www.hzmb.org/en/bencandy.asp?id=3075 |archivedate=18 October 2016 |df=dmy-all}} the last straighted-element of the {{convert|4860|m|ft|adj=mid|-long}} straight section of the undersea tunnel was installed on 12 July 2016,{{cite web |url=http://en.cccchzmb.com/P29-6459.biz |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-10-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018234725/http://en.cccchzmb.com/P29-6459.biz |archivedate=18 October 2016 |df=dmy-all}} while the final tunnel joint was installed on 2 May 2017. Construction of the Main Bridge, consisting of a [[viaduct]] and an undersea tunnel, was completed on 6 July 2017,{{cite web |title=Main structure of Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge is completed |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2017-07/07/content_30035204.htm |website=China Daily |accessdate=3 October 2017 |date=7 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170720210129/http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2017-07/07/content_30035204.htm |archivedate=20 July 2017 |df=dmy-all}} and the construction of the whole project was completed on 6 February 2018.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gov.cn/xinwen/2018-02/06/content_5264425.htm|title=港珠澳大桥主体工程完成交工验收具备通车试运营条件_滚动新闻_中国政府网|last=刘淼|website=www.gov.cn|access-date=2018-10-27}} File:Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge Site HK view 201506.jpg|Hong Kong section under construction in 2015 off the coast of [[Lantau Island]] File:Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge Eastern Artificial Island 8-May-2017 02.jpg|The eastern artificial island in May 2017 File:201805 Artificial Island of HKZMBridge.jpg|The Artificial Island in May 2018 File:HK-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge HK link.jpg|The completed Hong Kong section of the bridge in November 2018 == Sections and elements == The 55-km ({{Convert|55|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=out}}) HZMB consists of three main sections: the Main Bridge ({{Convert|29.6|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=or}}) in the middle of the Pearl River estuary, the Hong Kong Link Road ({{Convert|12|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=or}}) in the east and the Zhuhai Link Road ({{Convert|13.4|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=or}}) in the west of the estuary.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/breaking-news.php?id=116030&sid=3|title=China border control at sea crossing|work=The Standard|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.hzmb.gov.hk/en/|title=Hong Kong - Zhuhai - Macao Bridge|website=www.hzmb.gov.hk|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}} === Main Bridge === The Main Bridge, the largest part of the HZMB project, is a bridge-cum-tunnel system constructed by the mainland Chinese authorities.{{cite web |title=HZMB Main Bridge |url=http://www.hzmb.hk/eng/about_overview_01.html |publisher=[[Highways Department]] (Hong Kong) |accessdate=16 August 2018}} It connects an artificial island, housing the Boundary Crossing Facilities (BCF) for both mainland China and Macau in the west, to the Hong Kong Link Road in the east. This section includes a 22.9-km ({{Convert|22.9|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=out}}) viaduct and a 6.7-km ({{Convert|6.7|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=out}}) undersea tunnel that runs between two artificial islands. The viaduct crosses the Pearl River estuary with three cable-stayed bridges spanning between 280 and 460 metres (920 and 1,510 ft), allowing shipping traffic to pass underneath.Website of [[Transport and Housing Bureau]] ([[Hong Kong|HKSAR]]): [http://www.thb.gov.hk/eng/policy/transport/issues/cbt_3.htm "Cross boundary traffic: Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100118160158/http://www.thb.gov.hk/eng/policy/transport/issues/cbt_3.htm |date=18 January 2010 }}. Retrieved 22 December 2011.[[Arup Group Limited|Arup]] (a consulting company involved in the design of the bridges): [http://www.arup.com/Projects/Hong_Kong_Zhuhai_Macau_Bridge.aspx "Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macao Bridge overview"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100115102007/http://www.arup.com/Projects/Hong_Kong_Zhuhai_Macau_Bridge.aspx|date=15 January 2010}}. Retrieved 22 December 2011. === Hong Kong Link Road === Under Hong Kong jurisdiction, the Hong Kong Link Road was built by [[Highways Department|Highway Department]] to connect the Main Bridge to an artificial island housing the Hong Kong Boundary Crossing Facilities (HKBCF). This section includes a 9.4-km ({{Convert|9.4|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=out}}) viaduct, a 1-km ({{Convert|1|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=out}}) Scenic Hill Tunnel and a 1.6-km ({{Convert|1.6|km|mi|abbr=on|disp=out}}) at-grade road along the east coast of the [[Hong Kong International Airport]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.hzmb.hk/eng/about_overview_02.html|title=HongKong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge (HZMB) : Hong Kong Link Road|website=www.hzmb.hk|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.news.gov.hk/eng/2018/01/20180120/20180120_113410_060.html|title=Bridge link road surfacing completed|website=Hong Kong's Information Services Department|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.hyd.gov.hk/en/road_and_railway/hzmb_projects/6787th/HZM6844TH-PD0005.pdf|title=Plot of Hong Kong - Zhuhai - Macao Baridge - Hong Kong Link Road|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}} === Zhuhai Link Road === The Zhuhai Link Road starts from an artificial island housing the Boundary Crossing Facilities for both mainland China and Macau, passes through the developed area of [[Gongbei Subdistrict|Gongbei]] via a tunnel towards Zhuhai, and connects to three major expressways, namely, the [[Jingzhu Expressway|Jing-Zhu Expressway]], Guang-Zhu West Expressway and Jiang-Zhu Expressway.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hzmb.hk/eng/about_overview_06.html|title=HongKong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge (HZMB) : Connectivity to Pearl River West|website=www.hzmb.hk|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}}{{Cite journal|last=Yeung|first=Albert|date=2016-01-29|title=Geotechnical works of the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge Project|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/292213640_Geotechnical_works_of_the_Hong_Kong-Zhuhai-Macao_Bridge_Project|journal=Japanese Geotechnical Society Special Publication|volume=2|pages=109–121|doi=10.3208/jgssp.ESD-KL-3}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.hyd.gov.hk/en/road_and_railway/hzmb_projects/6787th/HZM6844TH-PD0005.pdf|title=Hong Kong Link Road (HKLR)|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}} == Left- and right-hand traffic == Although the HZMB connects two [[left-hand traffic]] (LHT) areas, namely Hong Kong and Macau, the crossing itself is [[right-hand traffic]] (RHT), the same as in Zhuhai and other regions of China. Thus, drivers from Hong Kong and Macau need to make use of crossing viaducts to switch to RHT upon entering the bridge, and back to LHT upon leaving the bridge when they are back to Hong Kong and Macau.{{Cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/02/21/cars-may-drive-right-hong-kong-zhuhai-macao-bridge-despite-citys-left-hand-traffic-arrangement/|title=Cars may drive on the right on Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge, despite city's left-hand traffic arrangement {{!}} Hong Kong Free Press HKFP|date=2017-02-21|work=Hong Kong Free Press HKFP|access-date=2018-11-01|language=en-GB}}{{Cite web|url=https://html2-f.scribdassets.com/4jy6fyf98g5q0dpy/images/15-456a6791f3.png|title=Interface of "Left-driving" & "Right-driving" Arrangement|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Traffic between Zhuhai and the bridge requires no left-right conversion as they are both RHT.{{cite news |last1=Su |first1=Xinqi |last2=Yeung |first2=Raymond |title=Right side of road the only way to travel on Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau bridge |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/economy/article/2133246/right-side-road-only-way-travel-hong-kong-zhuhai-macau-bridge |work=South China Morning Post |date=13 February 2018}} == Transport == === Shuttle buses === [[File:VR6495 at HZMB Zhuhai Port (20181024103741).jpg|thumb|Shuttle buses between Hong Kong and Zhuhai/Macau]] Shuttle buses are available 24 hours a day and depart up to every 5 minutes with tickets available for purchase from vending machines or ticket counters.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hzmbus.com|title=HZMBus|last=|first=|date=|website=www.hzmbus.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-22}} They take around 40 minutes to cross the HZMB. The HZMB Hong Kong Port can be reached from Hong Kong by taxis or various buses including CityFlyer airport (A-number) routes, or the B5 shuttle bus from Sunny Bay MTR station, or the B6 bus from [[Tung Chung]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.hzmbus.com/passenger_service.html?id=53|title=Shuttle bus services at Hong Kong Port (in Chinese)|last=|first=|date=|website=www.hzmbus.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-23}} The HZMB Zhuhai Port can be reached from the mainland by taxis or the L1 bus which uses historic tourist vehicles, or Line-12, 23, 25 or 3 buses.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hzmbus.com/passenger_service.html?id=45|title=Shuttle bus services at Zhuhai Port (in Chinese)|last=|first=|date=|website=www.hzmbus.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-23}} The HZMB Macau Port can be reached from Macau by taxis or various buses including the 101X bus and the 102X bus from St Paul's and Taipa, or the HZMB Integrated Resort Connection bus from Taipa Ferry Terminal or the Exterior Ferry terminal, connecting with free casino shuttle buses.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hzmbus.com/passenger_service.html?id=60|title=Shuttle bus services at Macau Port (in Chinese)|last=|first=|date=|website=www.hzmbus.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-23}} === Private vehicles and restrictions === Currently only 10,000 permits are available for private vehicles to drive across the HZMB from Hong Kong to Zhuhai.{{Cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/economy/article/2124010/hong-kongs-bridge-zhuhai-allow-7000-extra-cars-cross-after|title=Zhuhai bridge to allow 7,000 more cars after high demand|work=South China Morning Post|access-date=2018-10-25|language=en}} In addition, the number of vehicles permitted to enter Hong Kong and Macau from other regions is subject to a daily quota.{{cite web|url=https://www.td.gov.hk/en/public_services/licences_and_permits/closed_road_permit_for_cross_boundary_vehicles/rq_hk_private_cars_to_macao_access_city_centre/index.html|title=Transport Department - Regular Quota for Hong Kong Private Cars to Macao (Access to City Centre)|website=www.td.gov.hk|accessdate=22 October 2018}} Since the Hong Kong government imposes significant fees, taxes and administrative paperwork on private car ownership and usage to deal with road congestion,{{Cite web|url=https://www.moneyhero.com.hk/blog/en/how-much-does-it-cost-to-own-a-car-in-hong-kong|title=The cost of owning a car in Hong Kong|website=www.moneyhero.com.hk|language=en-HK|access-date=2018-10-22|date=2014-11-07}} driving a car on the HZMB would incur the same restrictions as current cross-border traffic. These include applying for separate driving licences for both Hong Kong and mainland China, a Hong Kong Closed Road Permit for cross-boundary vehicles, and an Approval Notice from the Guangdong Public Security Bureau.{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.hk/en/residents/transport/crossboundary/xb_driving.htm|title=GovHK: Cross-boundary Driving|last=(www.gov.hk)|first=GovHK|website=www.gov.hk|language=en|access-date=2018-10-22}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.td.gov.hk/en/public_services/licences_and_permits/closed_road_permit_for_cross_boundary_vehicles/index.html|title=Transport Department - Closed Road Permit for Cross-boundary Vehicles|website=www.td.gov.hk|language=en|access-date=2018-10-22}} Vehicle owners also need to ensure they have the appropriate insurance coverage for the regions they are travelling to.{{cite web |title=Insurance Authority - Motor insurance for using Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge (HZMB) |url=https://www.ia.org.hk/en/infocenter/faqs/faqs_13.html |website=www.ia.org.hk |language=zh-en}} == Economic effects == The HZMB links three major cities Hong Kong, Zhuhai and Macau, which are geographically close but separated by water. With the bridge in place, travelling time between Zhuhai and Hong Kong would cut down from about four hours to 30 minutes on the road.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-45937924|title=World's longest sea crossing: Hong Kong-Zhuhai bridge opens|date=2018-10-23|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en-GB}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2017-07/07/content_30035204.htm|title=Main structure of Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge is completed[1]- Chinadaily.com.cn|last=郭凯|website=www.chinadaily.com.cn|access-date=2018-10-28}} The HZMB project is part of a [[Beijing]]-driven strategy to create an economic hub and promote the economic development of the whole area of the [[Pearl River Delta]], which is also known as Greater Bay Area.{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/news/regional/2018/10/23/chinas-president-launches-hong-kong-mainland-mega-bridge/|title=China's president launches Hong Kong-mainland mega bridge - ASEAN Plus {{!}} The Star Online|website=www.thestar.com.my|access-date=2018-10-27}} Hoping to leverage the bridge and create an economic zone linking the three cities, Zhuhai's [[Hengqin]] area was designated as a free trade zone in 2015.{{Cite web|url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics-Economy/Economy/Hong-Kong-Zhuhai-Macau-Bridge-construction-set-to-finish-this-year|title=Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge construction set to finish this year|website=Nikkei Asian Review|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-10-28}} == Controversies == === Delays and budget overruns === The artificial island housing the Hong Kong Boundary Crossing Facilities (HKBCF) was reported drifting due to an unconventional method, hitherto unused in Hong Kong, for land reclamation with steel circular cells in a row pushed through the mud and filled with inert material to form a seawall.{{cite web|url=http://www.hzmb.hk/eng/doc/BCF%20Newsletter%20Issue%201%20E-A4.pdf|title=Newsletter 2012 July|date=July 2012|website=Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge and Related Hong Kong Projects|publisher=Highways Department|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126121032/http://www.hzmb.hk/eng/doc/BCF%20Newsletter%20Issue%201%20E-A4.pdf|archivedate=26 November 2015|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} The drifting of parts of the reclaimed island had allegedly caused a delay in the HZMB project. The Highways Department denied reports in various sources of movement up to 20 metres but admitted parts of the reclaimed land had moved "up to six or seven metres",{{cite news|url=http://www.ejinsight.com/20150923-island-drift-threatens-further-delays-in-cross-border-bridge/|title=Island drift threatens further delays in cross-border bridge|date=23 September 2015|work=Hong Kong Economic Journal|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126120958/http://www.ejinsight.com/20150923-island-drift-threatens-further-delays-in-cross-border-bridge/|archivedate=26 November 2015|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2015/11/25/delays-of-up-to-5-years-for-hk30bn-moving-macau-bridge-crossing-facilities/|title=Delays of up to 5 years for HK$30bn ‘moving’ Macau bridge crossing facilities|last1=Winn|first1=Howard|date=25 November 2015|work=Hong Kong Free Press|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126102937/https://www.hongkongfp.com/2015/11/25/delays-of-up-to-5-years-for-hk30bn-moving-macau-bridge-crossing-facilities/|archivedate=26 November 2015|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1860898/seven-metre-drift-hong-kong-artificial-island-reclaimed-bridge|title=Seven-metre drift on Hong Kong artificial island reclaimed for bridge project is normal, say officials|last1=Siu|first1=Phila|date=24 September 2015|work=South China Morning Post|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119185623/http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1860898/seven-metre-drift-hong-kong-artificial-island-reclaimed-bridge|archivedate=19 November 2015|deadurl=no|last2=Lee|first2=Eddie|df=dmy-all}} claiming that some movement was expected and safety had not been jeopardised.{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/article/1861223/shifting-sands-flaws-blamed-problems-artificial-island-hong-kong-zhuhai-macau|title=Shifting sands: 'flaws' blamed for problems at artificial island for Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau bridge|last1=Ng|first1=Kang-chung|date=25 September 2015|work=South China Morning Post|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151130023339/http://www.scmp.com/news/article/1861223/shifting-sands-flaws-blamed-problems-artificial-island-hong-kong-zhuhai-macau|archivedate=30 November 2015|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} Mainland contractors were also reportedly having difficulty in constructing immersed tubes in their section of the project, with the director of the Guangdong National Development and Reform Commission stating that 2020 would be a difficult target to meet. In 2017, the Main Bridge of the HZMB project experienced a cost overrun of about 10 billion yuan, arising from an increase in labor and material costs, as well as the refinement of the design and construction schemes.{{cite web|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/11/22/china-stretch-hong-kong-zhuhai-macao-bridge-hits-another-budget-overrun-totalling-hk11-7-billion/|title=China stretch of Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge hits another budget overrun totalling HK$11.7 billion|date=2017-11-22|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171206161803/https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/11/22/china-stretch-hong-kong-zhuhai-macao-bridge-hits-another-budget-overrun-totalling-hk11-7-billion/|archivedate=6 December 2017|deadurl=no|accessdate=2017-12-06|df=dmy-all}} === Worker deaths and injuries === The number of deaths and injuries that have taken place on the project has come under scrutiny in Hong Kong. Apart from nine fatal cases on the mainland side,{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-45937924|title=China opens longest sea-crossing bridge|date=2018-10-23|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en-GB}} there have been ten deaths reported on the Hong Kong side of the construction project, and somewhere between 234 and 600 injuries, depending on the source.{{cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/04/11/lawmakers-slam-govt-misleading-death-rates-related-hk-zhuhai-macau-bridge-project/|title=Lawmakers slam gov’t over ‘misleading’ death rates related to HK-Zhuhai-Macau bridge project|last1=Ng|first1=Ellie|date=11 April 2017|work=Hong Kong Free Press|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170413235316/https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/04/11/lawmakers-slam-govt-misleading-death-rates-related-hk-zhuhai-macau-bridge-project/|archivedate=13 April 2017|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} In April 2017, the Construction Site Workers General Union, the [[Labour Party (Hong Kong)|Labour Party]] and the [[Hong Kong Confederation of Trade Unions|Confederation of Trade Unions]] demonstrated at the [[Central Government Complex]], demanding the government take action.{{cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/04/12/govt-regrets-fatalities-hong-kong-zhuhai-macau-bridge-project-workers-demand-halt-murders/|title=Gov’t ‘regrets’ fatalities at Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau bridge project, as workers demand halt to ‘murders’|last1=Ng|first1=Ellie|date=12 April 2017|work=Hong Kong Free Press|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170414080754/https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/04/12/govt-regrets-fatalities-hong-kong-zhuhai-macau-bridge-project-workers-demand-halt-murders/|archivedate=14 April 2017|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} Lawmaker [[Fernando Cheung]] also expressed concerns over the unknown death toll on the Chinese side of the project, stating: "the project is known as the 'bridge of blood and tears’ and we are only talking about the Hong Kong side. We don’t even know what is happening in China. I suppose the situation could be 10 times worse than that in Hong Kong." He said that the Hong Kong Government had a responsibility to consider worker safety on the Chinese side. === Faked safety testing === In 2017, Hong Kong's [[Independent Commission Against Corruption (Hong Kong)|Independent Commission Against Corruption]] (ICAC) arrested 21 employees (two senior executives, 14 laboratory technicians and five laboratory assistants) of Jacobs China Limited, a contractor of the Civil Engineering and Development Department for falsifying concrete test results, thus potentially risking the safety of bridge for public use.{{cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/05/24/arrests-fake-lab-tests-mega-bridge-project-damages-trust-govt-lawmakers-warn/|title=‘Fake’ lab tests at mega bridge project damage trust in gov’t, lawmakers warn|last1=Ng|first1=Ellie|date=24 May 2017|work=Hong Kong Free Press}} In December 2017, a lab technician pleaded guilty and was sentenced to imprisonment for eight months, while the others await sentencing. Hong Kong's Highways Department conducted tests again after the falsified results were exposed and found all test results met safety standards.{{cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2017/12/01/lab-technician-jailed-8-months-falsifying-hong-kong-zhuhai-macao-bridge-test-records/|title=Lab technician jailed for 8 months after falsifying Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao bridge test records|last1=Cheng|first1=Kris|date=1 December 2017|work=Hong Kong Free Press}} === Seawall integrity === In April 2018, the public and media raised questions over the integrity of the seawalls protecting the artificial islands at both ends of the undersea tunnel. In footage taken by drone users and mariners, the [[dolos]]se installed at the edges of the artificial islands appear to have dislodged. Some civil engineers suggested that there was an error in design.{{cite news|url=https://lantaunews.com/2018/04/05/this-weeks-bridge-problem-tunnels-face-flooding-threat/|title=This week’s bridge problem: tunnel faces flooding threat|last1=Clark|first1=Robert|date=5 April 2018|work=Lantau News}}{{cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2018/04/03/hk-zhuhai-macao-bridge-components-found-drifting-artificial-island-authority-claims-may-illusion/|title=HK-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge components found drifting from artificial island, as authority claims it may be an ‘illusion’|last1=Cheng|first1=Kris|date=3 April 2018|work=[[Hong Kong Free Press]]}} In dismissing the safety concerns, the HZMB Authority said the dolosse were designed to be submerged and the design was working as intended.{{Cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/2140330/safety-concerns-over-artificial-island-mega-hong-kong-zhuhai|title=Drifting away? Concerns over Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau bridge dismissed|work=South China Morning Post|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en}} Director of [[Highways Department]] Daniel Chung denied on 8 April 2018 that the breakwater components had been washed away by waves.{{Cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2018/04/10/hong-kong-zhuhai-macao-bridge-breakwater-design-scientific-reasonable-safe-says-top-govt-official/|title=Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge breakwater design scientific, reasonable and safe, says top gov't official {{!}} Hong Kong Free Press HKFP|date=2018-04-10|work=Hong Kong Free Press HKFP|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en-GB}} Subsequent aerial footage posted online showed a section of the dolosse breakwater completely underwater. Civil engineer So Yiu-kwan told Hong Kong media on 12 April 2018 that the water level, at the time the photos were taken, was about 1.74 mPD (metres above Principal Datum), but the maximum water level could reach 2.7 mPD. He said the dolosse would offer no wave protection if entirely submerged, and further alleged that they had been installed backwards.{{cite news|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2018/04/12/sea-bridge-islands-breakwater-blocks-offer-no-protection-underwater-high-tide-says-veteran-engineer/|title=Sea bridge island’s breakwater blocks offer no protection as they are underwater at high tide, says veteran engineer|last1=Cheng|first1=Kris|date=12 April 2018|work=Hong Kong Free Press}} ===Falling number of dolphins=== Conservationists at [[WWF Hong Kong]] blamed the construction of the HZMB for the falling number of [[Sousa chinensis|white dolphins]] in the waters near the bridge. The dolphins found near waters of [[Lantau]] were worst hit with numbers dropping by 60 per cent between April 2015 and March 2016.{{cite news |title=Experts blame Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge for falling dolphin numbers |url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/1990312/experts-blame-hong-kong-zhuhai-macau-bridge |accessdate=28 October 2018 |agency=SCMP}} == See also '''Lustre''' is the [[codename]] of a [[secret treaty]] signed by [[France]] and the [[UKUSA Agreement|Five Eyes]] (FVEY) for cooperation in [[signals intelligence]] and for mutual data exchange between their respective [[Intelligence agency|intelligence agencies]]. Its existence was revealed during the 2013 [[global surveillance disclosure]] based on documents leaked by the former NSA contractor [[Edward Snowden]].<ref name="lemonde1" /><ref name="leparis">{{cite web|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/politique/espionnage-la-france-aurait-collabore-avec-la-nsa-29-10-2013-3268865.php |title=Espionnage : la France aurait collaboré avec la NSA |author=Le Parisien |work=Le Parisien |language=French |date=2013-10-29 |accessdate=2014-03-22 |archivedate=2014-03-22 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OGz9tnV6?url=http://www.leparisien.fr/politique/espionnage-la-france-aurait-collabore-avec-la-nsa-29-10-2013-3268865.php |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="numera">{{cite web|url=http://www.numerama.com/magazine/27347-lustre-la-france-aurait-coopere-avec-la-nsa.html |title=Lustre : la France aurait coopéré avec la NSA |author=Guillaume Champeau |work=Numerama |language=French |date=2013-10-28 |accessdate=2014-03-22 |archivedate=2014-03-22 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OGzKojEl?url=http://www.numerama.com/magazine/27347-lustre-la-france-aurait-coopere-avec-la-nsa.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="zdnet">{{cite web|url=http://www.zdnet.fr/actualites/espionnage-la-france-perd-son-lustre-39795120.htm |title=Espionnage : la France perd son Lustre |author=ZDNet.fr |work=ZDNet - France |language=French |date=2013-10-28 |accessdate=2014-03-22 |archivedate=2014-03-22 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OGzbCyjF?url=http://www.zdnet.fr/actualites/espionnage-la-france-perd-son-lustre-39795120.htm |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
{{global surveillance}}
== Historical background ==
The [[Directorate-General for External Security]] (DGSE) of France maintains a close relationship with both the NSA and the GCHQ after discussions for increased cooperation began in November 2006.<ref name=frlemjac>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/technologies/article/2013/11/29/la-france-precieux-partenaire-de-l-espionnage-de-la-nsa_3522653_651865.html |title=La France, précieux partenaire de l'espionnage de la NSA |author=Jacques Follorou |work=Le Monde |language=French |date=2013-11-29 |accessdate=2014-03-22 |archivedate=2013-11-30 |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20131130144856/http://www.lemonde.fr/technologies/article/2013/11/29/la-france-precieux-partenaire-de-l-espionnage-de-la-nsa_3522653_651865.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> By the early 2010s, the extent of cooperation in the joint interception of digital data by the DGSE and the NSA was noted to have increased dramatically.<ref name=frlemjac /><ref name="rfi-dgse-nsa-partnerschaft">{{cite web |url=http://www.rfi.fr/ameriques/20131130-espionnage-services-secrets-francais-precieux-partenaires-nsa-americaine/?ns_campaign=google_choix_redactions&ns_fee=0&ns_linkname=ameriques.20131130-espionnage-services-secrets-francais-precieux-partenaires-nsa-americaine&ns_mchannel=editors_picks&ns_source=google_actualite |title=Espionnage: les services secrets français précieux partenaires de la NSA américaine |author=Radio France Internationale |work=Radio France Internationale |language=French |date=2013-11-29 |accessdate=2014-03-22 |archivedate=2014-03-22 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OH01RbbB?url=http://www.rfi.fr/ameriques/20131130-espionnage-services-secrets-francais-precieux-partenaires-nsa-americaine/?ns_campaign=google_choix_redactions&ns_fee=0&ns_linkname=ameriques.20131130-espionnage-services-secrets-francais-precieux-partenaires-nsa-americ |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
In 2011, a formal [[memorandum]] for data exchange was signed by the DGSE and the NSA, which facilitated the transfer of millions of [[metadata]] records from the DGSE to the NSA.<ref name="lemonde1" /> In 2013, the existence of the Lustre treaty was revealed in documents leaked by the former NSA contractor [[Edward Snowden]].<ref name="lemonde1">{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/international/article/2013/10/30/surveillance-la-dgse-a-transmis-des-donnees-a-la-nsa-americaine_3505266_3210.html |title=Surveillance : la DGSE a transmis des données à la NSA américaine |author=Jacques Follorou |work=Le Monde |language=French |date=2013-10-30 |accessdate=2014-03-22 |archivedate=2013-11-01 |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20131101055116/http://www.lemonde.fr/international/article/2013/10/30/surveillance-la-dgse-a-transmis-des-donnees-a-la-nsa-americaine_3505266_3210.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
== Signatories == ;[[France]] * {{flagicon|France}} [[Direction Générale de la Sécurité Extérieure]] (DGSE) of France<ref name="lemonde1"/><ref name="leparis"/><ref name="numera"/><ref name="zdnet"/> ;[[UKUSA Agreement|Five Eyes]] * {{flagicon|Australia}} [[Defence Signals Directorate]] (DSD) of Australia * {{flagicon|Canada}} [[Communications Security Establishment Canada|Communications Security Establishment]] of Canada (CSEC) * {{flagicon|New Zealand}} [[Government Communications Security Bureau]] (GCSB) of New Zealand * {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[Government Communications Headquarters]] (GCHQ) of the United Kingdom * {{flagicon|United States}} [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) of the United States<ref name="lemonde1"/><ref name="leparis"/><ref name="numera"/><ref name="zdnet"/>
== Scale of surveillance ==
The French telecommunications corporation [[Orange S.A.]] shares customer call data with the French intelligence agency DGSE, and the intercepted data is handed over to GCHQ.<ref name="orangelemonde">{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/international/article/2014/03/20/dgse-orange-des-liaisons-incestueuses_4386264_3210.html |title=Espionnage : comment Orange et les services secrets coopèrent |author=Jacques Follorou |work=Le Monde |language=French |date=2014-03-20 |accessdate=2014-03-20 |archivedate=2014-03-20 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140320120950/http://www.lemonde.fr/international/article/2014/03/20/dgse-orange-des-liaisons-incestueuses_4386264_3210.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
From December 2012 to 8 January 2013, over 70 million [[metadata]] records were handed over to the NSA by French intelligence agencies.<ref name="lemonde1"/>

==Definitions== [[File:Kwashiorkor 6180.jpg|thumb|Child in the [[United States]] with signs of [[Kwashiorkor]], a dietary protein deficiency.]] Unless specifically mentioned otherwise, the term malnutrition refers to undernutrition for the remainder of this article. Malnutrition can be divided into two different types, SAM and MAM. SAM refers to children with severe acute malnutrition. MAM refers to moderate acute malnutrition.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|author1=Sathish Subramanian |author2=Sayeeda Huq |author3=Tanya Yatsunenko |author4=Rashidul Haque |author5=Mustafa Mahfuz |author6=Mohammed A. Alam |date=June 19, 2014|title=Persistent gut microbiota immaturity in malnourished Bangladeshi children|url=|journal=Nature |volume=510|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
===Undernutrition and overnutrition=== Malnutrition is caused by eating a diet in which [[nutrient]]s are ''not enough'' or is ''too much'' such that it causes health problems.<ref name="Clinical Nutrition in Practice (2011)">{{cite book|last=Nikolaos Katsilambros|title=Clinical Nutrition in Practice|year=2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-4443-4777-7|pages=37|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pJHU1m7BEP8C&pg=PT46}}</ref> It is a category of diseases that includes undernutrition and [[overnutrition]].<ref>{{cite web|title=WHO, nutrition experts take action on malnutrition |url=http://www.who.int/nutrition/pressnote_action_on_malnutrition/en/|work=World Health Organization |accessdate=February 10, 2012}}</ref> Overnutrition can result in [[obesity]] and being [[overweight]]. In some [[developing countries]], overnutrition in the form of [[obesity]] is beginning to present within the same communities as undernutrition.<ref>{{cite web|title=Progress For Children: A Report Card On Nutrition|url=http://www.unicef.org/nutrition/files/Progress_for_Children_-_No._4.pdf|publisher=UNICEF}}</ref>
However, the term malnutrition is commonly used to refer to undernutrition only.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite book|last=Nikolaos Katsilambros|title=Clinical Nutrition in Practice|year=2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-4443-4777-7|pages=39|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pJHU1m7BEP8C&pg=PT46}}</ref> This applies particularly to the context of development cooperation. Therefore, "malnutrition" in documents by the [[World Health Organization]], [[UNICEF]], [[Save the Children]] or other international [[non-governmental organization]]s (NGOs) usually is equated to undernutrition.
===Protein-energy malnutrition===
Undernutrition is sometimes used as a synonym of [[protein–energy malnutrition]] (PEM).<ref name="Young2012" /> While other include both [[micronutrient deficiencies]] and protein energy malnutrition in its definition.<ref name="Jones2011" /> It differs from [[calorie restriction]] in that calorie restriction may not result in negative health effects. The term hypoalimentation means underfeeding.<ref>{{DorlandsDict|four/000051473|hypoalimentation}}</ref>
The term "severe malnutrition" or "severe undernutrition" is often used to refer specifically to [[protein–energy malnutrition|PEM]].<ref name="Nutrition in pediatrics">{{cite book|editor-last3=Walker |editor-first3=W. Allan |editor-first=Christopher |editor-last=Duggan |editor-first2=John B. |editor-last2=Watkins |title=Nutrition in pediatrics: basic science, clinical application|year=2008|publisher=BC Decker|location=Hamilton|isbn=978-1-55009-361-2|pages=127–141|url=https://books.google.com/?id=wSTISCdSIosC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Nutrition+in+pediatrics+:+basic+science,+clinical+application#v=onepage&q=Nutrition%20in%20pediatrics%20%3A%20basic%20science%2C%20clinical%20application&f=false}}</ref> PEM is often associated with micronutrient deficiency.<ref name="Nutrition in pediatrics" /> Two forms of PEM are [[kwashiorkor]] and [[marasmus]], and they commonly coexist.<ref name="Clinical Nutrition in Practice (2011)" />
==== Kwashiorkor ==== [[Kwashiorkor]] is mainly caused by inadequate protein intake.<ref name="Clinical Nutrition in Practice (2011)" /> The main symptoms are [[edema]], wasting, liver enlargement, hypoalbuminaemia, steatosis, and possibly depigmentation of skin and hair.<ref name="Clinical Nutrition in Practice (2011)" /> Kwashiorkor is further identified by swelling of the belly, which is deceiving of actual nutritional status.<ref name="Chowdhury 2008" /> The term means ‘displaced child’ and is derived from a Ghana language of West Africa, means "the sickness the older one gets when the next baby is born," as this is when the older child is deprived of breast feeding and weaned to a diet composed largely of carbohydrates.<ref name="listeningga">{{cite journal|title=Listening to the Ga: Cicely Williams' Discovery of Kwashiorkor on the Gold Coast|author=Stanton J|year=2001|journal=Clio Medica: Studies in the History of Medicine and Health|volume=61|pages=149–71|pmid=11603151}}</ref>
====Marasmus==== [[Marasmus]] (‘to waste away’) is caused by an inadequate intake of protein and energy. The main symptoms are severe wasting, leaving little or no edema, minimal subcutaneous fat, severe muscle wasting, and non-normal serum albumin levels.<ref name="Clinical Nutrition in Practice (2011)" /> Marasmus can result from a sustained diet of inadequate energy and protein, and the metabolism adapts to prolong survival.<ref name="Clinical Nutrition in Practice (2011)" /> It is traditionally seen in famine, significant food restriction, or more severe cases of [[anorexia (symptom)|anorexia]].<ref name="Clinical Nutrition in Practice (2011)" /> Conditions are characterized by extreme wasting of the muscles and a gaunt expression.<ref name="Chowdhury 2008" />
===Undernutrition, hunger=== Undernutrition encompasses [[stunted growth]] (stunting), wasting, and deficiencies of essential vitamins and minerals (collectively referred to as micronutrients). The term [[hunger]], which describes a feeling of discomfort from not eating, has been used to describe undernutrition, especially in reference to food insecurity.<ref name="Black2008" />
===Definition by Gomez=== In 1956, Gómez and Galvan studied factors associated with death in a group of malnourished (undernourished) children in a hospital in Mexico City, Mexico and defined categories of malnutrition: first, second, and third degree.<ref name="Stevenson 2011">{{cite journal|last1=Stevenson|first1=R. D.|author2=Conaway, M. R.|title=Weight and Mortality Rates: "Gomez Classification" for Children With Cerebral Palsy?|journal=Pediatrics|date=August 2011|volume=128|issue=2|pages=e436–e437|doi=10.1542/peds.2011-1472|pmid=21768321}}</ref> The degrees were based on weight below a specified percentage of median weight for age.<ref name="Grover 2009" /> The risk of death increases with increasing degree of malnutrition.<ref name="Stevenson 2011" /> An adaptation of Gomez's original classification is still used today. While it provides a way to compare malnutrition within and between populations, the classification has been criticized for being "arbitrary" and for not considering overweight as a form of malnutrition. Also, height alone may not be the best indicator of malnutrition; children who are born prematurely may be considered short for their age even if they have good nutrition.<ref name="Gueri 1980">{{cite journal |last1=Gueri |first1=M.|author2=J. M. Gurney, P. Jutsum|title=The gomez classification. Time for a change?|journal=Bulletin of the World Health Organization|year=1980|volume=58|issue=5|pages=773–777|url=http://whqlibdoc.who.int/bulletin/1980/Vol58-No5/bulletin_1980_58(5)_773-777.pdf|pmid=6975186|pmc=2395976}}</ref>

===Definition by Waterlow=== [[John Waterlow|John Conrad Waterlow]] established a new classification for malnutrition.<ref name="Waterlow 1972"/> Instead of using just weight for age measurements, the classification established by Waterlow combines weight-for-height (indicating acute episodes of malnutrition) with height-for-age to show the stunting that results from chronic malnutrition.<ref name="J. C. Waterlow">{{cite journal|last=Watts|first=Geoff|title=John Conrad Waterlow|journal=The Lancet|date=December 2010|volume=376|issue=9757|pages=1982|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(10)62252-0}}</ref> One advantage of the Waterlow classification over the Gomez classification is that weight for height can be examined even if ages are not known.<ref name="Waterlow 1972"/>

==Effects== {{See also|Stunted growth|Wasting}} [[File:Sharecropper's child LC-USF33-002002-M2 (6288133677) (cropped) (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Child of a [[sharecropper]] with malnutrition and [[rickets]], 1935]] Malnutrition increases the risk of infection and infectious disease, and moderate malnutrition weakens every part of the immune system.<ref name="Stillwaggon 2008" /> For example, it is a major risk factor in the onset of active [[tuberculosis]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Schaible | first1 = U. E. | last2 = Kaufmann | first2 = S. H. E. | title = Malnutrition and Infection: Complex Mechanisms and Global Impacts | journal = PLoS Medicine | volume = 4 | issue = 5 | pages = e115 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17472433 | pmc = 1858706 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pmed.0040115 }}</ref> Protein and energy malnutrition and deficiencies of specific micronutrients (including iron, zinc, and vitamins) increase susceptibility to infection.<ref name="Stillwaggon 2008">{{cite journal|last=Stillwaggon|first=Eileen|title=Race, Sex, and the Neglected Risks for Women and Girls in Sub-Saharan Africa|journal=Feminist Economics|year=2008|volume=14|issue=4|pages=67–86|doi=10.1080/13545700802262923}}</ref> Malnutrition affects HIV transmission by increasing the risk of transmission from mother to child and also increasing replication of the virus.<ref name="Stillwaggon 2008" /> In communities or areas that lack access to safe drinking water, these additional health risks present a critical problem. Lower energy and impaired function of the brain also represent the downward spiral of malnutrition as victims are less able to perform the tasks they need to in order to acquire food, earn an income, or gain an education.
[[Avitaminosis|Vitamin-deficiency-related diseases]] (such as [[scurvy]] and [[rickets]]).
Hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) can result from a child not eating for 4 to 6 hours. Hypoglycemia should be considered if there is lethargy, limpness, convulsion, or loss of consciousness. If blood sugar can be measured immediately and quickly, perform a finger or heel stick.
===Signs=== In those with malnutrition some of the signs of dehydration differ.<ref name="WHO2005Chp8">{{cite book|chapter-url=http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2005/9241593180.pdf|title=The Treatment of diarrhoea : a manual for physicians and other senior health workers.|date=2005|publisher=World Health Organization|isbn=924159318 0|edition=4|location=Geneva|pages=22–24|chapter=8. Management of diarrhoea with severe malnutrition}}</ref> Children; however, may still be interested in drinking, have decreased interactions with the world around them, have decreased urine output, and may be cool to touch.<ref name=WHO2005Chp8/>
